channel.title: Stefan@eu90h.com's blog
channel.description: I write about Linux, programming, and mathematics.

item.title: The Gray-Scott Model of Autocatalytic Reactions
item.description: An exposition of the Gray-Scott model, ending with pretty pictures. Check it out!

item.title: Heat
item.description: An introduction to the Laplacian and heat diffusion. Finite difference approximations. Some numpy tricks. Let's get heated.

item.title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation: A Brief Outline

item.description: An informal derivation of Laplace's method.

item.title: Normalizing the Gaussian Integral: The Single-Variable Case
item.description: A brief note showing how to compute a 1D Gaussian integral.

item.title: The Prosecutor's Fallacy
item.description: A short exposition of the prosecutor's fallacy.

item.title: Deriving the Matrix form of Linear Regression

item.title: Ghidra on labwc on Wayland on NixOS: A Lesson in Java UI Toolkit Weirdness

item.title: Mind Your PyO3 Allocations!
item.description: Be careful about how you allocate memory with PyO3, otherwise your computer will explode.

item.title: Disable Window Decorations and Window Switcher Menu in labwc

item.description: This notebook demonstrates simple exponential smooth models using JAX.

item.title: Fitting an AR(1) model with JAX

item.description: This Kaggle notebook demonstrates a simple logistic regression model for the Titanic dataset using the JAX library.

item.title: McAfee ATR CTF 2021 Writeup
item.description: From February 5th to February 18th, 2021, McAfee's Advanced Threat Research team held a capture the flag (CTF) competition based on one held the year prior for its own employees. The challenges tested teams knowledge on topics ranging from recon, to cryptography, to rf hacking, and more. I had fun solving the challenges and learned a few things along the way. I decided to clean up the notes I had taken during the course of the competition and put them online in hopes they may be of later use.
item.author: Stefan

item.title: More Than You Ever Wanted To Know About C++ String Layouts
item.description: While working on a reverse engineering project (a malware sample written in Objective-C++), I noticed a certain motif which always appeared whenever the program was dealing with C++'s std::string objects.
item.author: Stefan
